reviews.review:
Great place to visit ..... Highly recommend you to visit Kopan Monastery while in Kathmandu... try to attend the chanting and prayers... such a relaxing place for meditation, while you enjoy a good 40 minutes walking to reach the place ...
Highly recommended to visit ...

The best monastery in nepal. It was my first opportunity to visit Buddhist monastery in kathmandu.
the place is situated in north part of kathmandu with mountain wiew as will virgin nature.
A little bit of Heven. Kopan is well worth a visit. So beautiful and peaceful. On our arrival we were met by a Monk who spoke English and answered all of our many questions.

Introduction to Buddhism Retreat - 10 days. Everyone should do this retreat once in their life - the earlier the better. The teachings are very insightful coupled with an introduction to meditation - just brilliant . Accommodation for the price is fantastic and the vegetarian food delish. Highly, highly recommend.

Beautiful and Peace. In the top of the mountain, with a such beautiful garden, it's Kopan. The monks are very kind and the main temple amazing. You have a book store too where you can find nice and cheap souveniers. Spend one day therer, meditating it's such a great experience.

My second home. Ever since my first 10-day introductory course here, Kopan has been not only my spiritual sanctuary but my warm second home as well. I long for this place as soon as I come back. Spending at least a few days here is so far one of the best things you can do for yourself. It is considered among the most important monasteries of Mahayana-Gelug tradition of Buddhism where resident monks constantly practice and chant mantras all day. If you are looking for a highly-spiritual, calm, tranquil time and learn what Tibetan Buddhism is from great great teachers, Kopan should be your destination. Om Mani Padme Hum!

Beautiful mountaintop view . Beautiful mountaintop temple view. Great experience. No crowds. I recommend visiting this monastery, especially because it's unlike anywhere else I visited around Kathmandu Valley.

Not popular, but truly amazing. You can see the Kathmandu from birds-eye view. That's not a very touristic venue, so when you come to the mess, you experience a real buddist serivice, heart-touching and mind-blowing...
Peaceful. Absolutely loved our trip up here. So peaceful and tranquil. The grounds are well manicured and its a great escape from the city. A newer Stupa compared to the rest, but it was beautiful!
new. one of the letest new morden cultural art monestry is kopan and near of tawn also good management we really like it
7 days Retreat in Kopan Monastery. An amazing inner journey discovering Buddhism & improve in a tremendous way meditation practicing with senior teachers
A must visit. I have seen many monasteries, but this one was just unique and nice and so peaceful the atmosphere..
Retreat course. I took a retreat course for meditation and budhism classes, which tourned out to be really good for having more of the local experience.
So peaceful, colorful and huge. Nice site to visit on a day tour. And highly recommended if you love Buddhist way of living, cultures and architectures.

One of the best place for retreat classes. Highly recommended place if you would like to learn about buddhism, meditation retreat classes run by the monks to have an understanding about the foundation of buddhism. It is located in a high location commanding a sweeping views of the kathmandu and international airport. The food in the vegetarian restaurant is a tasty choice for the travellers.

Located on top of the highest mountain with views over Kathmundu. I took a taxi to Copen, through some very rough roads lined with shops and stalls to the very steep top of the mountain where the monastery holds a beautiful position. Behind is an amazing garden with fountains, statues and many beautiful trees and plants overlooking Kathmundu far below.

Nice quiet place to escape the chaotic city. This temple is only a few km out of the city, but feels like the country side. Very quiet place for meditation, reading, hanging out... They offer 3 day intro to Buddhism courses and 10 day retreats. Visitors are welcome to admire the gardens, check out the temple, etc. There is a small cafeteria and an excellent bookstore. A cab from Thamel is approx 500Rs.
Peaceful. Visited the monastery in the afternoon. As we had not reserved any teachings, the guard was little unfriendly! Inside was peaceful. Beautiful compound. The lunch was good.
Perfection!!. Loved this place, beautiful in so many ways!! Well worth a visit! A bit difficult to find but worth all the effort, most likely will come back to this amazing place!
Great Monastery. Kopan offers lots of courses residential courses in Buddhism - we visited just to spend time in the grounds and met up with some friends. Amazing views of the city too.

Oasis with beautiful view . Kopan monastery is beautiful place on the hill with amazing view on the city! Inside is beautiful decorated park, perfect for take a little rest. There is also a library and a small shop.
There are many Budists around and the place is very peaceful :)
#there is NO entrance FEE, however take care Of the working hours.
Great. Kopan monastry is realy great manastry in kathmandu realy historically nice and central of tawns inside good invirment and secure must visit

A must visit in Kathmandu. A place away from all the city hassle. Peaceful. Beautifully maintained. The monks are helpful and they encourage visitors. You feel like sitting there for sometime and relax. The view in and from the monastery is stunning.
If you are in Kathmandu, you must never miss this place.

Blissful place for an amazing experience. I just completed the introduction to Buddhism, 7 day course at Kopan. First of all, Kopan is an absolutely blissful place! It's gorgeous and very peaceful. The course was a great experience. Both teachers (Jimmy and David) showed displayed knowledge, patience and were very helpful in answering all of our questions. It's a once in a lifetime experience that I would recommend to anyone who wants to learn about Buddhism, reflect on their own life and spend time in a very special place. Recommendation!
Beautiful Monastery. Nice place and nice gardens although I found some of the monks quite immature and aggressive with dogmatic views... A beautiful view though...

Kapan Monastery. Great place for mind refreshing. Meditation and nature loving place. We loved it when we went to see lots of Gumbas. After our 3 hours trip we find the Kapan Sekuwa Restaurant and had BBQ and MO MO. Great day out.
Buddhist Site. Kapan Monastery is located at north-east part of Kathmandu Valley. the monastery is beautiful with greenery garden.

Wonderful to visit. I did a ten day Beginners Buddhism course here and I really enjoyed.I loved the views, the gardens and listening to the beautiful chantings of the monks.The course itself was well planned and quite intense. I really enjoyed learning to meditate and being at the monastry was peaceful and tranquil. I also loved watching the little monks...the kids were so cute and are loved and cherished by the older monks.The food was tasty and helping with the dishes now and again was a small price to pay. Also the shop with books, bags and the necklaces were also very reasonably priced.

Very beautiful Monastery at the top of the hill. Very nice and secluded monastery, it is located at the top of a hill so it has great views of the city, the monastery is very well maintained and very beautiful, worth a visit

a great Buddhist athmosphere. Several times I did a 10 day Intro-course Buddhism at Kopan. It's like a magical place. If you stay there for a few days, you feel like it's your home! The monks are very friendly. From the Kopan hill, there is a beautiful view over Kathmandu :-)

Monastery. one of the monastery that is not over crowded its like quite inside of the main kathmandu. like i mean in the street area. Good people around and its good to visit right here. Quite easy to reach here by walk or even if you want you can take public transport from anywhere around.
Beautiful Monastry on the top of the hill.. A wlking distance from Boudhanath Stupa, Kopan has great Monastic area with clean and hygienic restaurant, great library and beautiful garden to rejoice.

"Don't cut yourself short". Give yourself plenty of time when you come to the Kopan Monestary for a visit. This is a visit you can also easily do on your own, you do not need a guide unless you really want one. There is no admission fee, a taxi from the Thamel will probably run you about 500 Rupees each way. This is a fairly new Monestary, so it's not like you need a guide to explain all the history here, it is more of a working Monestary and School. Bring a picnic and eat out in the beautiful gardens. Or better yet, schedule to take one of their classes, that will be my net trip here, definitely worth multiple visits. This place is pretty magical, inspirational, friendly and very scenic. Not just the beauty of the monastery , but the grounds are kept immaculate, beyond anywhere else I have visited, especially in Nepal. They have a restaurant (vegetarian) here, that is very clean and has gorgeous views of the entire Kathmandu valley. Service and food are average, but this obviously helps support the monastery. You can take silent meditation classes here, for a week or ten days if you are strong enough. I believe they also teach basic Dharma classes as-well. This is also a destination for visiting monks from other countries. IN the past they did not allow photographs within the main Monestary, that has changed, and you may now take photos at least when the hall is not in use. My suggestion would be a donation of about 20-50 Rupees per picture, you can just leave it at the base of the Dali Lama's picture. There is a gift shop and bookstore with very reasonable prices, and a very extensive selection of books, mostly in English. Also a Receptionist who can walk you through the various options if you wish to stay here. When you visit, get here in the morning, there is a security guard, and he will have you sign in, and give you a guest pass, there is no charge for visiting. However everything, possibly even the front gate closes between 11:30 and 1:00 or 1:30, so plan that time for your lunch break and wait for the monastery to re-open in the afternoon for further exploration. A truly wonderful place to visit, top 5 probably in the Kathmandu valley, at least for me.

Peaceful and Scenic Location Away from the Chaos. I took a taxi to the Kopan Monastery on a whim. I hadn't seen as much about it as other sights in Kathmandu but decided to visit. It's a bit of a trek to get there with some winding roads full of potholes but well worth it. The monastery grounds are beautiful and well manicured and the view overlooking the city is quite stunning. I would definitely recommend a visit.

My Fav Place in Kathmandu. This place is hard to get to and proportion of it is off road down back streets and alleys. Local taxi from Thamel should cost no more than 500 R and a lot of it is also up hill.This place undoubtedly has a sense of calm and serenity away from the city. Monks are all friendly and approachable and the garden and it's sculptures are just amazing. I spent an hour in the grounds just relaxing on the grass while there.
Peaceful. One of the greatest place we've been. Great and loving people inside.. So quite and peaceful. Go for it, but be respectful with the monks
Stroll Up to Kopan Monastery. A wonderful introductory trek to marvel the rich cultural and religious heritage of Kathmandu. Don't miss the library at the Kopan Monastery !
Peaceful and Beautiful Place. If one is searching for peace of mind, then this is the place to go. I recommend to go there and spend some time.
no words to express ... This place has soo much to offer you.. very peaceful, clam.... Best place to understand and study about Tibetian Buddhism .. nice time pass

Beautiful Monastery with a Great View of Kathmandu!. Many lovely features to the monastery--the 360 view of Kathmandu being one of them, plus beautiful stupas, statues, and prayer wheels. Fun to see the younger students. Gift shop is great as well and inexpensive. Coffee shop is a good place to end the visit.

Top place in Kathmandu. Of all the places I visited in Kathmandu , this was my favorite, it starts with a taxi ride up a hill, avoiding all the hazards, and then dropped outside a gate, now what to do , walked down the road to a larger monastery , but no entry, came back to the large brown gates, cautiously pulled back the lock and wondered in, the building are lovely as are the shrines, no one talks or hassles you ,and no tourists about, great views, very peaceful and relaxing . It Is a great place, a bit of a hassle to get to, but the advantage of this is less tourist ( like myself) , when you leave, with the gate to the back of you, take the little path to your right down the hill, a lovely walk, get you back to the main roads to get a taxi

Best intro to Bhuddist culture and understanding . I helped coordinate a group tour with Fran at Kopan. Kopan was a little off the beaten path, but well worth the time. The temple grounds are beautiful and offer equally impressive views of Kathmandu. In the morning a the monks debate. It is quite a lively time to be there. Mid morning there is a daily Dharma talk. Ours was given by Monk Tingyal. It was poignant and thought provoking. The group of students enjoyed the talk the most. They have a lovely book store on the premises. They sell a variety of books, CDs, DVDs, pashminas, singing bowls, and various Buddhist materials (prayer flags, door hangings, prayer beads, etc.) The prices are much more reasonable than anywhere else in Kathmandu. They have a lovely area to enjoy lunch. The menu was much more extensive than just dhal bhaat (which surprised me).Truly a wonderful way to spend your morning. I highly recommend starting your day here and going to Bouddha afterwards.
Grand. Amazing big and nice!Many people!Buddist monks! Amazing how buddist pray and bring food to offer! Bananas, Apples etcYou feel the difference to EuropeDo not miss it

10 day introductory course. I loved Kopan from the moment I entered. The environment is so calm, happy and peacefull. A friend and I were there for almost two weeks and I was sad to leave. The Monks were kind, our wonderful teachers who spent hours trying to answer our endless questions were amazing, and even the staff working there were terrific. The course was intense but I learnt a lot, wish I was there to be able to practice better. I think one forgets very quickly once away from the monastery.I must mention taxi driver Ganesh who hangs just outside the monastery. His telephone number is+9779803558800. He was reliable, very patient and spent a few days driving us around .Pic includes.By the way anyone shopping for prayer wheels etc, found good stuff and prices at Swayambhunath Temple, including pic of shop.

"Very peaceful &away from crowd ". This place is far away from the city noises and atmosphere. It is at a good height thus allowing you to see a good view of kathmandu too. The monks are friendly, I even managed to make friends with them. Really good place. I myself being a tourist, was really keen on exploring the importance of Buddhist values. Well after that visit I'm more than satisfied.

10 day course was very good!. Stayed here for the 10 day course and it was great. Beautiful place and amazing people. The teachings are good and the set up as well. Food is the same everyday, so be prepared for that. I would highly recommend this place!

Stay within a Buddhist monastery. 3 nights in this peaceful environment was soul enriching. The elevated setting above Kathmandu offered good city and mountain views, especially at sunrise and sunset. The gardens are beautiful and the food and accommodation good. I felt welcomed by the monks and was honoured to share their space for a short visit. Visitors are encouraged to experience daily meditation and talks. There is an excellent shop so bring some money to buy quality Buddhist items, including books and DVD's.

Outstanding way to spend a week. From the moment you enter the feeling of peacefulness and serenity pervades. The accommodation is comfortable but basic and the food, whilst taking a bit for western tastebuds to acclimatise, is a sensory delight. There is much to be learnt here and if you immerse yourself in the lessons and mediations I guarantee you will emerge better for it. Again, simply outstanding

An Amazing Buddhist Monastery!. I fell in love with this Monastery. IT is so peaceful, enchanting, and spectacular. The Monks are welcoming and answer all your questions. It was beyond my expectations !

Peaceful and without turists. I've walked from Boudha and while taking pictures and not rushing it took me an hour. Walk itself isn't much pleasant due to dirty roads but you can easily spot a day to day life of local people. Monastery itself is very nice, especially the part of Thousand Buddha stupa. I've met only 3 foreigners during my visit but a lot of monks and student monks.

Underwhelming, not a priority. This is a monastery whose business it is to host people coming for retreats, as well as the local monks. The architecture really isn't that spectacular and you'll get better views elsewhere, especially when there's smog. If you're really into the religion/culture, it's fun to see the monks debating, but really, it's pretty far away and underwhelming after seeing Patan and Bhaktapur.
Hindu Heaven. A very full place with several rotating prayer columns. Turn them clockwise for your prayers to come true! Festively decorated monks, and a lot of different sites.

Nice location and view. The monastery is a bit outside of the city center but worth the trip. Unfortunately we were not allowed inside but the view of Kathmandu from the garden was nice and away from pollution. We saw lot of monks on lunch break and they were nice and friendly and chatted with some visitors.

Amazing Monastery Life. I stayed 5 nights there. You can forget everything about your daily life in your country. You can meet not only monks who practice dharma but also people from all over the world. Day by day, you will find your own meaning of your life.

Kopan worth a visit when in Kathmandu. Many people wonder whether favourite places such as Kopan Monastery will look the same as before the quakes therefore it was a wonderful to visit Kopan on the weekend and find it looked as splendid as ever with very little damage to see. The main temple looks magnificent and most of the accommodation and other buildings are fine. The gardens and the stupa area look glorious in the spring. Kopan is set high on the hills behind Boudha and you can walk there, take a taxi or local bus. Kopan is a Gelug monastery and runs meditation and Buddhist courses and these have now started again. From Kopan there is a great half hour walk on a well made trail along the ridge to Pullahari Monastery with panoramic views of Kathmandu Valley. A visit to Kopan with the walk to Pullahari takes about 3 hours.

Peaceful Retreat. Despite only having a day at Kopan Monastery, I found it to be a peaceful and restorative place to visit. It is situated above Kathmandu and away from the hustle and bustle of the traffic in town. The views are superb and the gardens beautifully laid out. We enjoyed a meal at the cafe before wandering through the gardens and extensive grounds. The library and bookshop were very interesting and we saw many study groups in action around the monastery. I would like to spend more time at Kopan and find out more about what they have to offer. My overwhelming impression was of a welcoming and accepting community where you can find space for reflection and solitude.

Must visit . Took a bus from the Old City station near Thamel to Kopan. It will be a pricey taxi ride. Bus ride was about 45 minutes. It drops you off in the village and I was fortunate enough to have a local walk with me to show me the direction to the monastery. Otherwise look up what it looks like beforehand as you can see it on the hills and can also figure your way out that way also. It is quite the steep uphill walk took me probably another 45 minutes from drop off to monastery. You can also catch a cab if you don't want to walk. Do not wear shorts as I saw a girl get rejected at the entrance even though they were to her knees. This place is absolutely a lovely retreat perched atop the city. Lovely views. You cannot enter the actual monastery however. There is a cafe and a library there that has odd hours so it may be closed. A very interesting stupa with tons of relics also. Enjoy the temple grounds here. If you are feeling adventurous like I was I am not sure of the name but there is a huge red temple atop a hill in very clear view from here. You can walk there in 30 minutes on a lovely scenic dirt path. Ask locals the direction of "Pulahari" and you will come to a clear blue and red archway that says welcome. Then a steep uphill to get there but I found the monastery itself more impressive than Kopan it was stunning. Another 30 minutes from here is Pulahari a third monastery not as impressive as the other two in my opinion however. A monk informed me these temples used to be open for people to enter but the insides are so damaged now and are being reconstructed. All these temples had lovely views and scenic paths full of prayer flags to each destination.

Meditators Trap. The 5 day course of "how to meditate" was very misleading and perhaps should have been called Budhism advanced. We were bombarded with very detailed theories and beliefs of the religion and later we were informed that they only talk about the breathing because we think meditation is about breathing. This would have been good if it had a different name that didn't mention meditation.

An oasis in busy and dusty Kathmandu. Quiet! Peaceful! Relaxing! A great place to escape from busy Kathmandu and get a glimpse of what monastic life is. If you are interested in Tibetan Buddhism and around in November, don't miss the month-long residential course held there. It is a life-changing experience!Namaste_/\_

The Introduction to Buddhism course. I spent 12 days here in January 2015. I did the Introduction to Buddhism course there and it was one of the best things I've ever done. Many teachings and group meditations in beautiful surroundings. Joan, (a nun originally from Canada) the course leader was excellent and patient with us.The concepts and ideas we discussed and learned about have stuck with me since then and I continue to pursue the practice.

Best place for peace of mind !. Our driver recommended us to visit Kopan Monastery while we were visiting Pashupati Nath Temple and Buddhist Stupa. This was a really nice place , I wish I had time for meditation .....

Peak into the Monastic Life. Kopan Monastery is a wonderful place to visit for anyone interested in Tibetan Buddhism. You can either enjoy the exercise of walking up the hill to Kopan or catch a taxi. Once you're inside the gates at Kopan it is a treat to explore the beautiful grounds, enjoy a bit to eat at the cafe and take in the many gifts available at the book store. (This may be one of the best spots to buy books on Buddhism in Kathmandu.) If you're lucky there will be a puja happening and you can peak into the prayer hall and listen to the enchanting puja.
Relaxed place. I stayed there for one week, you can check in there website about retreat, if they won't have it, you can stayed there. It is a relaxed area

A serene gem. The travel up to see this place was as interesting as the place itself as no real road signs- However stunning views over Kathmandu, serenity and beautiful gardens all make this place somewhere worthwhile to visit. The gardens are immaculate - It is also a large Buddhist retreat, hence the peace and quiet which was refreshing coming from the hustle and bustle of Kathmandu. -sadly the book shop closes at lunch time.

Brilliant cultural experience. This place is somewhat away from the city noises and atmosphere. It is at a good height thus allowing you to see a good view of KTM too. The monks are friendly, I even managed to add a few on Facebook. Really good place. I myself being Nepali, was really keen on exploring the importance of Buddhist values. Well after that visit I'm more than satisfied.
color full monastery. this place is so power full and so color full ..you can doing meditation.. you are in and other place when you stay there.. a small paradise.
Peaceful. A very peaceful and relaxing atmosphere to hang out away from the busy capital noise and pollution. A must visit

C h i l l O u t. If you can't feel the vibe here then you must be made of stone.I walked here through lots of very suburban residential areas coming from Budhanilkantha, the pathway leading slowly up the hills, increasing the stunning view of the Katmandu Valley as you rise up and up. Once you arrive at the monastery don't be shy, knock on the door and the security will let you in. Once in relax, walk slowly, take it in, sit down and rest, eat some lunch in the restaurant/cafe. I had Nepali Thali and it was 5 star, the curd was perfect, i mean PERFECT!Check it out.

A morning of peace... This is a lovely spot to gather your thoughts and take a time-out from the noise and congestion of the city. Lovely views of the valley as well. The small cafe serves delicious foods too!
A MUST SEE. A great peaceful place with a fantastic bookshop but check the website for opening dates as the monastery closes when private teachings/courses are running.

Peaceful. Great place to visit for peace of mind & also wonderful view of Boudhanath & other areas. You can also see hills/mountains on the other side. You can go there for meditation, learning about buddhism or just to relax & have food in their cafe.

Perfectly peaceful. I visited Kopan Monastery on a whim, on the recommendation of a fellow traveller who I met while out wandering around Pashupatinath. I caught a taxi out to look around, and was totally drawn in to the beauty and peacefulness of this place. A great place to go to sit and relax, far from the hustle of Thamel!

I feel like family here.... I didn't just visit Kopan I stayed in their guest rooms. I have made fellow traveler friends for a lifetime; but also monk friends who I consider family. They have awesome grounds and facilities. Their library and book shop is outstanding. The cafe for snacks is hands down awesome and inexpensive! I fell in love with honey ginger lemon tea here. I left and came back because even at nice hotel in Kathmandu I wondered why am I not at Kopan? I left again for a short trip to Lumbini and injured myself and had to come back same day - they provided me room and help and care until I recovered. All of this and daily dharma talks and mediation? You can't go wrong.

A Stunning Garden. Peaceful and beautiful. Not grand, but worth the trip up the Lazimpat Road. Occasionally the Monastery is closed if there is a retreat. There are many fine and exceptional places to visit in Kathmandu. If want to visit somewhere out the centre and away from the tourist haunts (stunning as they are), make your way here. Maybe take a picnic, sit on the grass, enjoy the detail of the temples and the many tiny figures representing the life of Buddha. You will need transport. To the left of the entrance to the monastery is a row of shops, keep them on your left, go to the right of a set of tall metal doors and take a walk along the path. Further along you get good views of Kathmandu.

gud place to meditate. kopan monastery is nice place to meditate, mini buses available from thamel & durbar marg & nearby places for rs.20, usually overcrowded. nevertheless you'll get some place to travel & people usually guide you if u ask. not many people knw english, so asking some college folks or in some restaurants/shops might help you. bus drops u near to kopan, so u'll have to walk & trek a little by asking people.(excuse gps). once u get to monastery you have library cum shoppe of souvenirs & a canteen cum general store for some purchases. rest you can explore.
for those who want to learn about Budism. Nice courses about Buddhist meditation, with great teachers and awesome food! Nice view from the city, mainly Boudha Stupa.
Amazing. The temple is peaceful, has an amazing view, awesome Buddhas sculptures. Before entering, there are a number of words of wisdoms, which are extremely useful to apply to our daily life.

nepal. the monastery is nice but seeing the students painting was inpressive,they are resonablye prices and will bargain,cheaper than in town there,try a cart ride around the town,tell them 15 max,theyll give u a great tour

Beautiful . A great day out from the busy streets of kathmandu, amd it's an adventure getting there. set high on a hill with good views weather permitting, an excellent library, and grounds. there was some restoration going on due to the earthquake which was interesting to watch, and even with the fuel crisis, the cafe made Momo's. Well worth the visit. Make sure you check visiting times

The view from this place is amazing!. When hanging out in Nepal a lot you tend to miss the nature and somewhere to be without the constant noise of traffic. Kopan is a wonderful place to go either for just a day or for a retreat. The atmosphere there is relaxing and it is simply beautiful there. Retreats are a bit pricy though, but heir door is always open even just for a one-day visit.

If you visited Namo Buddha - skip this. The monastery it big but the part that is accessible to public is small. If you have time, do go to this. But if you have to choose only one monastery in Nepal, I would recommend you visit Namo Buddha.
The monastery by itself, without comparison with others, is very nice.
wonderful place. this is a place where of buddist where they will worship god budhha which was is beatiful place and i had visited this place by @Rosha Trek & Expedition P. Ltd.

5star. I love being there it is so peaceful and great experience visiting here
One must visit here if he really want to explore the peace

Place of peace in busy city. Not far from boudha stupa Kopan monastry is worth a visit both for the views over the city and for the lovely quiet temple and gardens. The cafe is also really nice. Just lower down the road there is also a nunnery- the temple was closed when I visited as the nuns where having lunch outside though they didn't mind me wandering in and offered me lunch. It's a shame it's not as well maintained as the male monastry.
Peaceful place. We made it up the hill to give donation for the earthquake victims. Whilst there we took in the sights. There is a bodhi tree and 2 stupas to circumambulate - just beautiful.

A lovely place to spend some time. Kopan is a large Buddhist monastery a half hour or so walk north of the Boudhanath stupa in the hills above Katmandu. I took a taxi through some increasingly pleasant towns in the Katmandu valley. The enclave is typically difficult to get into although I didn't know that when I appeared at the entrance and got a lukewarm "Oh go ahead" from the guard. I strolled around inside, keeping clear of an area where signs said a retreat was going on and wound up at the highest point in the monastery grounds where there is a wonderfully sculptured park with peaceful sitting areas all around. After capturing some of the beauty with my camera I sat down on a bench and meditated. Someone sat down near me and then more came and I realized I was in the middle of a discussion group from the retreat. They were all glowing and we chatted for a little while before I got out of their way. A lovely place to spend some time and retreat from the chaos of Katmandu even if you don't go on their meditation retreat.

Worth the trek. If you have the opportunity to trek up the mountain and visit Kopan Monastery, you should! First the views are impressive. On a clear day, you can see all of Kathmandu below and it is just beautiful. My favorite part was joining the free meditation class they offer in the morning. I was one of the most memorable parts of my trip.From here, I walked down to the Boudhanath Stoupa. It was a 35-40 minute walk. Do not try it on a rainy day, unless you have really good rain boots. Regardless, it was a wonderful experience!

Nice place, cafe and shop but main monastry is closed at the moment . I enjoyed the 7.6km walk from thamel, however it was not clearly notified when I emailed the monastry, that during courses, day vistors can not enter the monastry and the grounds on that level at all, which does limit significantly what you can experience there.Needless to say it was a pleasant time visiting the cafe, library and shop but be warned if you expect more! Courses finish on the 14th December I was told so better to go after.

Good place. The monastery lies at the top of hillside, norther of Kathmandu valley. The architecture of the monastery is so great.Can see mountain and valley view from the same place. This place is a good place to relax and meditate

A Nice Hike out of the City.. We hiked here from Boudhanath Stupa in about an hour. The best way to get here, by foot, is to just follow the street that seems to be going in the right direction. The Kopan can be seen on the hilltop from almost anyplace in this side of Kathmandu, so it would be hard to get lost. Occasionally there is a small sign tacked to a pole that states 'Kopan Monastery', with an arrow. But these are few and far between. Once you get close to the structure, there is a little path that winds its way up the hillside to the top of the hill. There are some grand gates here that, for us, were barring entrance - as there was either some very important ceremony going on, or the construction near the gate to repair the earthquake damage was too concerning to allow tourists inside.However, there is a another gate just 30 seconds back down the road, directly behind you as you face the main archway. It is large, and has no signage. You just knock on the door. A guard opens up a small sub door, makes sure you are not wearing any leather and that the girls have their shoulders covered - we you're in.The monastery is wonderful, the grounds are spectacular, and the views of the city are well worth the hike. There is also a little store and cafe next to a small patio that overlooks Kathmandu. It was all very magical, as the clouds boiled up and gave us a wonderfully dramatic sky for our visit. The interior of the monastery is so complex, colorful, and ornate - perfectly Buddhist.
beautiful blissful place. a bit far from everywhere, definitely a day trip and just spend time soaking in, being away from polluted thamel and city center.

Beautiful Spiritual Place. Well worth the long winding road up to this gorgeous place. We were welcomed and invited to sit and listen to the chanting which was indescribably wonderful and moving. The beauty of the art and the architecture along with the sight of hundreds of maroon clad monks of all ages is something I will long remember even though no photos were allowed inside.

incredible experience. They teach you how to live your life ! It s not a theological religion, they just believe in afterlife.They reprogram your brain to eliminate all the negatives taughts It's an experience of a lifetime !

Exquisite detail in the temple. We fronted up to the locked gate of the Khachoe Chakyil Ling Nunnery (known as the Kopan Nunnery) ready to explore only to discover that it was closed for a special religious ceremony. Rajesh was particularly disappointed, as he knew we would love what was behind the gate, but instead we strolled along the narrow hillside path to the Kopan Monastery further up the hill where the new gompa (temple) rises as an impressive beacon to devotees and visitors alike. This is a very new building, completed in the 1990s, and as such is in pristine condition – the cleanest and most magnificent we have seen. A boy monk of about 10 years of age showed us around the facilities, impressive in his knowledge of his faith and the monastery, as well as his maturity and serenity. He patiently waited while we explored, provided explanation when we paused, and cheerfully farewelled us when we headed off. He’s got it all sorted that one.
Lovely stroll up to Kopan. Of course, one can hire a taxi but a walk through the busy city makes this visit even more special; a realm radiating peace.

Spiritual Bliss !!!. Visitors are allowed only on Saturdays and it will be crowded, one of the most beautiful place to visit and take some photos and videos to cherish for entire lifetime ,10days in house meditation camp is conducted here.When we sit in silence after doing all the formalities we will be absolutely peaceful and feeling relaxed.Thanks a lot for everything,Loving you so much,Peacefully yours,S M Bega Raaj.Happy travelling...

10 day course!. Had a great experience here for a 10 day course. Great teachers, beautiful setting, affordable and clean accommodations. The food is good, though not amazing.Great opportunity to learn and relax.
peace of mind. located on the hill top with the great view of valley including bouddhanath stupa and Himalayan range. participated in puja ceremony , i got refreshed. will come back again

If you are a Buddhist, it is a MUST see. The Kopan monastery is famous for its Buddhist studies mostly for foreigners. Also the monastery itself is worth to see. Situated on a hill overlooking Kathmandu. It is a little difficult to go there... long taxi drive.

Wonderful monastery with beautiful garden and views. Kopan monastery is a very beautiful and peaceful place to visit. The temple is stunning. And, the views of the surrounding village are expansive. To the right of the temple is a large garden which contains two ornate stupas and a seating area. There is also a display of small statues which illustate key moments in the life of the Buddha nestled in plantings at the entrance to the garden.
Kopan Monastery in Kathmandu. A good location for self cultivation on Tibetan Buddhism. Road access are repairing, hopefully to be better and completed soon.

Wonderful visit to Kopan Monastery. Big Walk from the hotel where we stayed and once reaching the place, it is just like getting the satisfaction of climbing Stone Mountain in Atlanta. Kopan Monastery is nicely maintained and beautiful pictures to be taken.

serene and beautiful. We stayed here 4 nights. Beautiful scenery and nice monks. Food is very simple. It was great to experience a monastery, and learn about meditation. Rooms were clean and good sized.
Very nice to see. very unique and should see, its different what u see in yr country, clean and nice whether, bring along yr drinking bottle
good hike. makes for a good hike on a weekend. Though now, roads up to the monastery has been made. The monastery itself is very beautiful and spacious. Also, provides a good view of the surrounding.
Loved to visit. Since of thangka lover.... i love every buddhist monastery.. Kopan is one of my best monastery in Nepal
A blissful place. A blissful place . Amazing view of Kathmandu City , Himalayas and surrounding hills . Want to meditate ? Want to learn about Buddhism ? This is the place !

Place of Peace and Spiritual Enhancement. A great place for de-stressing by meditation, attending prayers, listening to the Buddhist monks at prayers. We organized a special Buddhist Marriage for our friends from Ireland and Philippines several years back and it was awesome. The experience is just awesome.

Educational relaxation. I visited back in January for the '10 day Beginners' Course,' and it is one of the reasons that I have saved up to head back to Asia. The experience that you experience there never leaves you. With an introduction to Buddhist philosophy and mediation, a library and cafe, gorgeous views, interesting lectures, lovely nuns and monks in conjunction with great company will have one ready to return for the another (longer) course. You don't walk out of those gates the same person. Until the next time, Kopan!
best relaxation ever. wonderful private stay at kopan in late august. simple rooms and food. excellent views, quiet, and interesting people.
Great place!. A great sight to see! Highly recomend. The people of Nepal are super friendly and this place is no exception!

Very good for retreat, friendly to non-buddhist balance seekers. I would love to stay here for retreat - it's very friendly to foreigners, the monastery has stunning view over Kathmandu. Come and live here for a while...

Magical place!. What an incredible place to visit! Peaceful, quiet and sums up a huge amount of the Buddhist culture you come across. Although only 15% of the Nepali population are Buddhist, there is an overwhelming Buddhist theme wherever you go. This place explains more then anywhere else! I hear you can stay here. It is apparently a great experience. Well worth the walk up and the wander around. Take time to sit out in the garden to watch the Monastery school children. So delightfully happy.

KOPAN Monastery. I attended the Monastery for the yearly Lam Rim Course they open to international people there. The monks were warm and friendly and physically move out of their usual quarters to allow for the visitors.

Peaceful and inspiring. It's worth a trip to Kopan which is only a short taxi ride from Boudhanath or a 45 minute walk (that's how long it took me from the Stupa).I enjoyed watching the monks praying and chanting in the main temple, wandering around the very wel kept gardens, browsing in the extensive bookshop, reading in the library and chatting to a monk about the Dharma in the cafe (which has OK food). The views are very good and the air a little cleaner than down in the valley (a welcome respite from the city's pollution).It is worth checking that it is open before heading up there because it can be closed if they have a busy course or retreat - phone the reception.

nice view. the view of kathmandu valley was very nice, but our trip there was a bit rocky/shaky maybe because of the earthquake or maybe because the driver didn't know his way and took us on dirt roads :) the garden and the inside of the monastery are nice
the view .. was stunning. the view from the monastery was breathtaking. The sun was up but the not so cold breeze balance the hot temperature. which made our visit was lovely and wonderful.
Geluppa dharma center. This monestry is of Buddhist nearby hill if Kathmandu. Where people go, pray and meditate. You can see many Lama(Monks) there and view of valley as well.
Buddhist monastery. A bit away from the town this monastery is situated in middle of the Budanilkantha and Boudha Stupha.

Perfect respite. Take a taxi, or find somebody who will take you for a walk out there - great cross-country pathways if you can find them. Enjoy the monastery, do a little shopping, have a wonderful lunch and soak in the view of the Himalayas behind you and the Kathmandu Valley in front of you.

You can't get in unless you're on a course. Hi. Our taxi driver suggested that we go up there so we agreed but it was not open and the guy on the gate said it was never open. I asked why tour tourists were allowed in and he said it's because they are on a course. So just an FYI

Loved the atmosphere!. We stayed for a 10 days intro to Buddhism session. Under Ani Karen's class. On the first day there were at least 120 students, on the 10th day, a little over 60 remained. The food was delicious, and the chanting was pleasant to listen to. It was a very calming atmosphere. The experience is what you make of it, if you dedicate your time to learning you can get a lot from the course.

Great!. My mom and I came for a week, we did a private stay and it was the perfect amount of time. We were not terribly familiar with the Buddhist religion, but were treated very well and all our questions were answered. The library was a great resource to use, there is a cafe, but meals are provided by the monastery too. The convenience store has essentials if you forget anything or want snacks, and the monks are incredibly nice! It was a great, relaxing stay so I would recommend trying it out! Dharma talks are good to attend, and I want to come back for a course, everyone I talked to have them glowing reviews!
Peaceful. Listening to the chanting of the monks early in the morning was such a tranquility. Wish I stayed longer, 5 days were too short.

Great place to chill & observe. The Kopan Monastery is a great place to observe the workings of a monastery. We spent ages in the library and spent a lot due to the quality of goods.Stay Strong Nepal & PrayForNepal

A room with a meditative soundtrack. I had the opportunity to do a private stay (between official retreats and programs, the monastery is open to the public for guesthouse bookings). The place inspires a sense of tranquility and rest. I had a room close to two main meditation halls and a courtyard and was thrilled to hear the chanting of monks in the morning and evening. Staying here is quite affordable and is a welcome respite from the dust and business of the city.

Magical Place. We were able to go inside the monastery, because we had a friend inside, a monk. Who was so very kind to show us the whole place, the praying center is unbelievable and huge. A truly Buddhist place. If you are interested in studying Buddhism for some months, this could be an ideal pleace.
see it. It depends on someone interest to like it or not. You feel calm while you are here. If someone like quite place its fine, otherwise so so.....
Peace and meditation. You can not dislike this place. It will provide the best place for meditation and give your mind some peace from hectic life.

Peaceful gardens. After hiking to Everest Base Camp we came back down to the madness of Katmandu. Our last day there we decided at the recommendation of our hotel manager to go to Kopan Monastery and I ever glad they did. It is a wonderful quiet get away high above the city. It is a school of sorts where others can come for a week and study the Buddhist lifestyle and take courses. The grounds are amazing full of quiet places to hide away in. The Monastery itself is beautiful much like the others. What makes this one different are the grounds and the children preparing to be monks walking around.

Amazing experience!!!. I was very lucky to have the opportunity to stay in this place for 12 days. Magical! The 10 day course is amazing and can be life changing, great insights. This place is very different from the rest of the agitated city: Calm, very clean and full of green. If you can, sleep there and learn about Buddhism, if you can't at least pay a visit. The Gompas are really beautiful. It is not old as the Hindu temples, but it is really magical.

Beautiful, serene and views. This fairly newly constructed Buddhist monastery is an example of how rich foreigner funding can create something very special in the middle of Kathmandu. Also, this is on top of a hill, so you can somewhat escape the grime and noise of the city below. Many Americans will be found here doing a 'retreat' so you need to be quiet and respectful. The buildings exteriors and interiors are beautiful and well maintained. The views from on the top of the hill are worth the trip. Security guard at the entrance. Lots of monks, both young and older. Lots of grass areas and a beautiful temple in the middle. We didn't look into what they offered to foreigners, but I am certain many foreigners spend days or weeks there.
Wonderful Escape!. Don't miss out on the Kopan experience when in Kathmandu. Stunning property that offers a glimpse of how monks live. Beautiful architecture and views.

A must must place to visit. A place that will calm you down - we went their on our last day of stay in Kathmandu and it was the best way to end a very nice trip. Beautiful grounds looking over the sprawling valley, beautiful monastery and very nice and friendly people. Catch the prayer around noon, visit the library (nicely-priced souvenirs for sale, perfect gifts to take home for folks) and eat at the restaurant with windows to the sky. Do visit.

If you are interested in meditation. This is the place to be, to take some courses or just spend some days in the monastery and read a lot of books, is amazing how you begin to be with yourself. worthy to try. This place helps you to travel inside yourself, which is very difficult to do.

Perfect place for intro to meditation....check out your exit!. I spent the day of my Father's 'death anniversary' here.I wanted to find time for myself and experience meditation with others, have peace, and find whatever I seem to looking for. I got a taxi from The Radisson in Kathmandu- my taxi driver tried so hard to convince me that he should stay and wait for me, but I sent him away (BIG MISTAKE!).Anyway, the monks were in meditation in the big hall, so I sat and meditated, chanted with them........wonderful, except for the number of people who seemed intent on taking pictures/videos rather than being in the moment. I sat for hours, and was included in the water giving and really relaxed and joined in. It was quite simply lovely. I then went for a walk around the gardens, which are amazing, made especially special by the monks, meditating, playing games and just being here, who add to the special feeling.I had a packed lunch with me, so at about 3pm I decided to head off home.....and find a taxi.....none to be seen. The gate man advised me to follow the monks, who were walking down to Bodhnath, but being my own and my first day in Kathmandu I was really nervous. When I asked about the bus (aka lonely planet guide) I was told that would be the next day. I had felt quite relaxed as there were so many 'westerners/tourists' there, but found out they were mainly on organised retreats/longer stay, not day visitors.So, panic set in!I felt a real failure as my only option was to ring the hotel and get them to send a taxi!I went back into the gardens to try to dissipate the panic and 'asked the universe' to get me to Bodhnath. I know this sounds like rubbish.....but after about an hour I went back to the main gates, and there was a taxi bringing back some monks. I reserved it, went back inside and asked if anyone else wanted a lift. There was one other chap (Australian) in the same boat as me, so we went halves and got down to Bodhnath.I am sure now that following the monks would have been an Ok thing to do, just dusty and pretty busy, so even for a now hardened, Kathmandu tourist, not sure I would choose to do it.SO, for the cost, if had my time again, I would ask my taxi man to wait for me! In summary. A WONDERFUL escape from Kathmandu, and if you have your exit planned, you would have a lovely day of meditation in a perfect environment, with lovely monks and superb gardens...and a feeling which is hard to describe.. a peace and connection with the closest I think it is possible to get to Tibetan monks as a tourist with a short time as your disposal.PS: * Food is spasmodic* English speaking Monks not a given* Toilets are squat, bring your own paper* Plan for transport

Little Monks. The most attractive part of this monastery is there are monks of the age of 10-15 years old. Most people throng there to get a snapshot with the young monks.... this is on top and the thrill of climbing 100 steps to monstery

Zen. Had intended to attend the daily dharma talk (mon - fri) but went on a Saturday when no talks were held. One lama gestured that we can stil enter the meditation hall where dharma talks are usually held. Purely sitting in the well kept hall was an amazing experience for me. Such a calm feeling. There are more to see in Kopan monastary such as miniatures in the garden showing stories of Buddha. It would be good to contact the monastary first before visiting the place since it might be closed on major buddhist festivals.

Well-managed Monastery. I had visited Kopan Monastery for three years consecutively. I stayed in their guest house which is not the best in Kathmandu but we always named it as Hilton - Kopan. The rate is not cheap but the environment is peaceful and clean. Food is available in the cafe and again the rate is higher that some cafes around. Suggest to visit the New Sadle(New Skill and Developement Learning Experience) It is an NGO providing treatment for leprosy people, beggars, other disable and marginalized people medically and rehabilitate cured social outcast as well as polio and other Disable. You can help them by paying them a visit and buy some of their products.
Peace. A beautiful place to stay if you just want to know more about Tibetan Buddhism. You can stay for a course or just for having some rest
nice, bit of a hike. great peaceful atmosphere, but of a hike to get up here. Nice to hang around and soak up the peaceful atmosphere.

Amazing out of the city day trip. Kopan Monastery is a nice day trip out of Kathmandu. It's beautiful, provides a great view of the valley.You can watch the monk students do a ritual, as well. They have classes there as well for people to learn about Buddhism, it was created as a monastery for westerners originally.
But even just for a trip, it's lovely.

Beautiful and quiet temple. The Kopan monastery is especially famous for teaching Buddhism to visiting Western foreigners. Its a quiet and beautiful space on top of the hills of Kathmandu. If your ida of Nepal was to have some kind of peaceful retreat this definitely worths a visit.
MONASTERY STILLNESS. I liked stillness.I spent in the Kopan Monastery3 weeks.It was unforgettable being in company all day long with the 250 monks.

Peaceful place for mediation. On top of Kathmandu hill you can find this Thibetian monastery with peaceful area for praying and mediation . Many travelers come to here for retreat with this great atmosphere and sincere teaching

When you leave, you leave with a kinder heart.. An amazing place whether you are Buddhist or not. It is stunningly beautiful with many different levels of accommodation to suit everyone. The food is delicious and the very ground seems to exude peace and tranquility. I will go back as often as can manage.

PEACE. Peaceful place, with nice location the sorroundings are clean and looks nice in a way but overall if I say will be a gud to visit and mst visit place in KTM. Lot to learn and earn knowledgewise and one must visit this place.

Do visit!. If you want to learn about Buddhism or take some teachings, courses, retreats- it's a perfect place!Located beautifully on top of the hill away from the noise of Kathmandu city.A great place to study Buddhism or to just get away from it all even for few hours( DO CALL them first if you want to visit to make sure they will let you in. If they are helding retreats, they don't let people go in) .They offer 7 days or 10 days retreats every month. A perfect place to study Buddhism. There is a small shop with great books, little vegetarian cafe on side with great view of Kathmandu. Highly recommend!

Far but Good. This Kopan Monastery or Kopan Gumpa is definitely located away from all the other attractions in kathmandu valley. It could be a bit difficult to get here. I went here after going to Boudanath Stupa. Took me an hour to get with a bike. The road is not good (as like everywhere else). But the Monastery itself is not too impressive. so probably you can give it a pass if your schedule is tight.

Nice place. Kopan is a beautiful Tibetan monastery on the outskirts of Nepal. It's worth a visit to see the nice compound with all it's statues, stupa and decorations. Or to sit down for a day, relax and read or write. The monastery also has an extensive library and a small shop with a lot of interesting books on Buddhism.
professional. good location, still profssional. but monk, nun, views are like a worthful , friendly. i been 2 hours there, taking a tea with nice views
Beautiful. Very beautiful place with nice views all around. There is a shop and a library. Nice relaxing gardens, statues and fountains around.

Tranquility & great views of the Valley!. Kopan was on the last day of our itinerary and it was like an excellent parting treat! It was a about 45min drive from our hotel in Durbag Marg. The uphill climb was a bit rocky with poor roads, but it passes by villages and you get a glimpse of the life around. You will see monks going up and down the hill. The guard at the entrance gate was not ready to allow us in and luckily we met a monk entering the monastery. He gladly agreed to take us inside and also explained what to see. We were told that all the monks had gone to Bodhnath Stupa. We were all by ourselves at that time. It was such a peaceful environment. We spent time going around the beautiful garden at the back where you will find a couple of stupas and then the main meditation hall and the souvenir shop.It is nice break from the chaotic Kathmandu. You get nice view of the valley and Bodhnath Stupa. Definitely worth a visit!

Just OK but.... The monastery was great and theres so much history to this place but I didn't find it as nice as others.. but I did enjoy the beautiful walk to this place, the people along the way and that pointed me to the direction of this place was great, so saying that I do recommend this place

The best discovery of Buddhism. This monastery is a place to learn about Buddhism. There are several courses depending on the level of teaching you are searching. The monks and nuns are very open to help you.The rooms are good and clean with hot water! The food is vegetarian and great.I will be returning there and would recommend it to every one.

This place stirred something in me. We made the 40min walk from Boudhanath Stupa up, which was quite easy but then we walked straight past the sneaky walkway up. Lucky a couple of young monks found us and led us back. It was supposed to be closed at the time of year we went but the guard happily opened the door to us. And it was magical. The views, the people, the serenity. I plan on returning to stay for a few weeks next time I'm in Nepal.

Bliss. It's on the outskirts of Kathmandu and has amazing views of the city. You can stay in their lodges and attend the morning poojas. The guided meditation is very good and it's always so interesting hearing the monks stories. It is cheap accommodation and is a good alternative to staying in the city.

Nice peaceful area. But more suited for those interested in buddhism and spirtuality (imo).. As a regular tourist without a more-than-average interest in spirituality and Buddhism it was just an alright place to visit for me. You do have amazing views on the city and can see Boudhanath Stupa from the well maintained and peaceful gardens there, but the monastery and religious side of things didn't interest me that much.

Peaceful and Serene. The bumpy ride from Thamel up to Kopan was an enjoyable one as we saw many locals and how they live. Past the monastery gates, however, was a delight. It was very quiet even though we saw some young monks discussing and enjoying themselves in the warm, winter sun. We took lots of photos and ventured around to the garden which beautiful. Most of the trees still had foliage (I think there were a few colourful plastic trees too!)Pleasant to see visitors and locals alike relaxing and doing some yoga on the green above a spiralling brick staircase in the garden.Gift shop was amazing as they had a Bounty bar (of all things on a mountain) and lots of other souvenirs, and cashier was manned by a robed monk which was lovely to see.

Love monastries!. I have a fascination for monasteries and they never fail to mesmerise me!Kopan is away from the city, quiet and beautiful!Stop by to meditate for a while in the monastery, speak to the locals, and then to sip a cup of coffee at the coffee shop at the monastery.....!
Spiritual. Very clean place, especially after visiting hindi temples, very peaceful and with great views. Totally recommended

A retreat from the noise. A serene place with a nice view of kathmandu. A little far from the city, but worth it. You won't find taxis from there, so keep the taxi that you brought waiting. It would take about half an hour to roam around.

Amazing Experience. Very peaceful, away from the crowd & beautiful place to visit for few hours but I won't rush my visit if I happen to be there next time. The holy places should be taken care very well but found this place unclean which is unfortunate.

Must Visit.. Highest point, that allows you views of the city, interaction with some monks, some peace and quiet from the city, and finally a place where there is none of the kathmandu pollution. There is a nice shrine at the back of the monastery.

A hidden gem. Most short trips to Kathmandu don't have this monastery in their list of places to visit. However, I found it to be fantastic. A 15-20 minute drive from boudhnath stupa, including a short climb, takes you to the monastery. You get a brilliant view of Kathmandu from here. We requested that we would like to be shown around, and a nice monk promptly obliged. We saw the main building, the school, canteen, gardens etc etc. There is a small shop and a restaurant also inside. We made a small donation at the end. The whole place is very quiet, and you get a lot of information about Buddhism. In addition you can see little kids who will spend some years here in the school. Must visit if you are going to Boudhnath. The entire tour takes only 30 mins, but you will enjoy it.
The most tranquil, peaceful setting in Kathmandu. If you have nothing left to do in Kathmandu, just simply visit Kopan and take a breather from the Kathamandu-ness.
Wonderful walk up the hill. Very open to westerners, with a cafe and bookstore on site. It makes a nice half day trip to hike up the hill from the Bodha stupa to Kopan monastery.

Beautiful air. If you want some fresh air, away from the hustling and bustling of the streets of Kathmandu then well this is the place to be. You will get lost in the various carvings on the temples and its serenity.

"I ll say one of the best place to be in kathmandu!". Monastery apart the place and sorroundings are very peaceful and feels like you aren't in Kathmandu's crowd rather feels like you are seeing kathmandu from up above the sky !
Peaceful and quiet. Very peaceful and quiet place on a hill. You can get a beautiful view of the valley from the monastery. The temple of 1000 Buddha is mind blowing.

Where the Mystic Meets the Soulful. Ah! Kopan! What a place of serenity and spirituality! The Kopan (Tibetan, Buddhist) Monastery lies in the outskirts of Kathmandu (a 45 minute drive), atop a hill that rises over the valley. I'd imagine it's not the easiest place to find in Kathmandu. Entry is free and certain courtesies, expected. A Muslim and mostly ignorant when it comes to Buddhism, I can only comment on the aesthetics. Kopan is a complex of monasteries, shrines (?), a nunnery, cafeteria and I guess what could be called 'retreats'. The shrines are a shimmering Golden and adorned with intricate designs. The hilltop offers a great view of the Kathmandu valley. There are shade-trees for a quick read, or gazebos for quiet meditation. The 'retreats' are restricted area for tourists since they're likely to disturb the peace of monks and trainees. A lot of Europeans / Westerners come here for spiritual guidance and peace of mind and can often be seen with their cleaning-buckets, mops or gardening tools - working tirelessly and happy as clams.Great place to visit for 2/3 hours of quiet. A chat with a local monk makes it even more special.
Not worth a short trip. This may well be a great place to enjoy a Buddhism course (I don't know) and the location is peaceful enough, but too far from the city to warrant a couple of hours visit.

Peaceful place, best place to spend several days. I have attended 10 day discover Buddhism course in Kopan monastery. Peaceful quiet and comfortable place to spend time here, get new experience, learn meditation and stay with yourself. Gompa is new but very nice. Excellent views. Quiet place in Kathmandu valley.
Someway away from Kathmandu. A modern complex but perhaps not worth the trouble? I liked the foreign visitors doing meditation stays.

Blissful to aquire wisdom and to find yourself. I went there in May this year for a ten days retreat and to learn about buddhism..I was not disappointed. My stay was a memorable one. The monks and the nuns were so serene and helpful. The place in itself is so serene and peaceful. There are many corner areas where you.can sit and.meditate. My retreat was to learn about buddhism and learn meditation. I came out with a hand full of.wisdom and plenty of books. The canteen food is good. The rooms k chose were 5.star ;) the bookstore was awesome. U can spend a whole day there. And meditation were divine. Pure bliss to be there. Very close to Bodhnath area. From Bodhnath one way.up is NPR 150 app but more expensive from Thamel or Kathmandu. The views are just amazing. What a peaceful place to find yourself. There are specific time and days the monastery is open for visitors. You may even consider staying there at a cost..No hesitations. Just go.

A peaceful Buddhist site. Kopan Monastery consists of two monasteries on top of two adjacent hills, and is free to enter, though one of the monasteries was off-limits the time I visited due to a "Pooja." The one monastery was enough to visit though. I found the place by bicycle and by asking locals at every turn in the road.Though perched atop a hill, the views of Kathmandu are never great due to the smog. The site has a number of well preserved buildings used for Buddhist prayers and rituals. Lots of Buddhists on site shuffling around in their traditional red garb. Of particular interest for tourists is the large prayer wheel, and the garden with the two large Buddhist shrines, very colourful and intricately carved. A few restaurants are available.

Peaceful Place.... The Drive their was a task through the Kathmandu city itself...Situated on the hill had great views..The Monastery had great vibrations, lovely place to meditate...the gardens are very well kept and tell some history about Lord Buddha ...
Easy to see. Hard to find.. I could see it but had no idea where to go. No signs at all. No clear path. Monks smiled but did not help. Never got therePretty views. Take a taxi.

Oasis of peace. A beautiful monastery set in the Kopan hill of Kathmandu. A few new blocks have been built to accommodate retreatants who wish to attend its Buddhism or meditation courses. The rooms in the new blocks are clean and nicely furnished. For its price, it is very decent and value for money and one should not compare with those of 4 or 5 star hotel. It's in a monastery after all. It has both a canteen, which is a simple cookhouse that offers free meal, and also a cafe, that serves a decent spread for a small price. Visit the garden at the back of the monastery and view the two beautifully decorated stupas which are built to commemorate two of the monastery great lamas who have passed on.
kopan. great views, great gardens, very well stocked and very fairly priced goods in shop. Good range of courses, simple but nice cafe
quiet. Kopan is one of the most beautifull places. It is so clean and quiet and parcipating in the meditation calsses is absolutly unforgetable

Completed a course at Kopan. A truly amazing experience. The teachings and the meditation are life changing. The only downside was the basic facilities and cleanliness, which unfortunately made it difficult for me to focus on the course.
Far but worth it. This quite far from kathmandu but worth a visit for your discovery of life of the monks.An interesting culture.

Wonderful place.. Kopan is my favourite place to visit, it's so peaceful, get there in time to enjoy a great breakfast or lunch in the café. A taxi will take you there from Thamel and wait an hour or so for around 1300 rupees (less than £10)

Kopan Peace. a wonderful monastery outside of the city! its a oasis of tibetan buddhism and set on lovely landscape!

Awesome. Kopan Monastery had its beginnings in the Solu-khumbu region of the Himalayan mountains. In 1971 Lama Zopa Rinpoche, the reincarnation of the Lawudo Lama, a yogi of the tiny hamlet of Lawudo, fulfilled the promise of the previous Lawudo Lama to start a monastic school for the local children. The school was called called it Mount Everest Center. Twenty five monks moved down from the mountain to Kopan in 1971 - prompted by the harsh climate at an altitude of 4000 am, which made study barely possible in winter.Now Kopan is a thriving monastery of 360 monks, mainly from Nepal and Tibet, and a spiritual oasis for hundreds of visitors yearly from around the world. Nearby is Khachoe Ghakyil Ling Nunnery, home to 380 nuns. Both the monastery and the nunnery are under the spiritual guidance of Lama Zopa Rinpoche, and the care of the abbot, Khen Rinpoche Geshe Lhundrup Rigsel. And it is the wellspring of the FPMT, a network of some 140 centers and activities world-wide, themselves expressions of the Buddha activity of Lama Thubten Yeshe and Lama Zopa Rinpoche

Highly recommend the 10 day course. I have just finished a 10 day course at Kopan and it was an incredible experience. The schedule was pretty packed - from 6am to 9pm most days, with a break in the middle of the day, but I didn't find it was too much. The teachings were so interesting and really helped me to understand the nature of the mind, attachment and suffering. The daily group discussions were also a highlight as you get to hear the way others perceive things which really makes you think about your own perceptions. The grounds at Kopan are beautiful and it's so nice to hear the monks' chanting in the mornings and evenings. The library is really well stocked and there are so many interesting texts to read. I found the morning and evening practice of silence really calming, although unfortunately some people in the group couldn't stick to it. The food at Kopan was so much better than I expected and was different almost every day. The accommodation I had wasn't great...I was in a very hot shared room at the back of the property next to the animals with hundreds of mosquitos (which you have to take a vow not to kill) and barking dogs, so make sure you take ear plugs. To be fair though, I signed up really late to the course so I was in the most basic of the accommodation. People who signed up early were in really nice rooms with private bathrooms and even had air-con which I had to try every day not to be envious of! The only bit of constructive criticism I'd give is that since it was a beginner's course, I would have liked the teachings to be more practical and explain how to incorporate them into my daily life and thought processes. I felt it was a little too focused on achieving enlightenment, which, to people who are just learning, seems like a lofty, far off goal. Other than that, the experience was so positive I am now considering doing the one month course in November.
